rounds.text: The Sahara Desert is the largest desert on Earth by total area.
Honey never spoils due to its low moisture content and high alkalinity.
Cleopatra lived closer in time to the building of the Great Pyramid than to the invention of the iPhone.
Bananas are technically classified as a type of tree.
Russia spans 9 time zones, more than any other country.
The human nose can detect over 1 million distinct scents.
Thomas Edison is credited with inventing the telephone in the 1870s.
The capital of Australia is Sydney, the country's most populous city.
Mars is the hottest planet in our solar system due to its thick atmosphere.
Octopuses have three hearts and red blood.
Napoleon Bonaparte was known for being unusually short, standing around 5'2".
Glass is technically a slow-moving liquid, which is why old windows are thicker at the bottom.
The Great Wall of China is the only man-made structure visible from space with the naked eye.
Goldfish have a memory span of about three seconds.
Vikings wore horned helmets into battle.
Shakespeare is credited with coining roughly 170 English words still in use today.
Mount Everest grows about 4 centimeters taller each year due to tectonic activity.
A group of flamingos is called a flock.
The famous phrase "Elementary, my dear Watson" appears frequently in Arthur Conan Doyle's original Sherlock Holmes novels.
Switzerland has been a member of the European Union since 1995.
Babies are born with around 270 bones, which fuse down to 180 by adulthood.
Sushi refers specifically to the raw fish used in Japanese cuisine.
The Canary Islands were named after the canary birds native to the region.
Lightning never strikes the same place twice.
The painting on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel took Michelangelo roughly 20 years to complete.
A jiffy is just slang with no actual scientific definition.
rounds.correctWord: an actual unit of time in physics and computing

rounds.text: Chameleons change color primarily for camouflage.
The blood in your veins is blue until it is exposed to oxygen.
Albert Einstein failed math as a student.
Brazil is named after the country's founder, Pedro Brazil.
Humans use only 10% of their brains at any given time.
The brace position on airplanes is designed to preserve dental records for identification.
Fortune cookies originated in China before spreading to America.
Bats are completely blind and navigate solely by echolocation.
The word "robot" was coined by Isaac Asimov in his science fiction stories.
The Hundred Years' War between England and France lasted exactly 100 years.
Peanuts are classified as tree nuts.
The inventor of the Pringles can is buried in one, per his final request.
Ostriches bury their heads in the sand when frightened.
rounds.wrongWord: bury their heads in the sand

rounds.text: The hashtag symbol (#) is technically called an ampersand.
Wombat droppings are round, which prevents them from rolling away on sloped terrain.
The national animal of Scotland is the stag.
An average cumulus cloud weighs roughly 1,000 pounds.
Strawberries are a true berry, botanically speaking.
The ancient Olympics awarded solid gold medals to winners.
Sharks must keep swimming to stay alive because they cannot breathe while stationary.
The original Star Wars film was the first movie to use CGI.
Redheads require less anesthesia during surgery than people with other hair colors.
Mount Kilimanjaro is a dormant volcano located in Kenya.
The total surface area of human lungs is roughly the size of a parking space.
Oxford University was founded after the Aztec Empire began.
Carrots were originally white before being selectively bred to be orange.
The yo-yo was originally developed as a weapon in ancient Greece.
A photon of light takes about 8 minutes to travel from the Sun's surface to Earth, and about 100 years from the Sun's core to its surface.
Humans share approximately 90% of their DNA with bananas.
The Dead Sea is a sea located between Israel and Jordan.
Coca-Cola was originally green before artificial coloring was added.
A day on Venus is shorter than a year on Venus.
Cleopatra was Egyptian by ethnicity.
A mantis shrimp can punch with the force of a bullet, making its claws the hardest biological substance known.
rounds.correctWord: fastest strike (tooth enamel and limpet teeth are harder)

rounds.text: Maine is the closest US state to the continent of Asia.
Tomatoes were once considered poisonous by Europeans because they are related to deadly nightshade.
rounds.correctWord: their acid reacted with lead pewter plates, causing lead poisoning

rounds.text: The dot over a lowercase 'i' and 'j' is called a serif.
An average person walks the equivalent of three times around the Earth in their lifetime.
The shortest war in history lasted 45 minutes, between Britain and Zanzibar.
Honey bees can recognize individual human voices.
Greenland is the largest continent in the world.
The patent for the fire hydrant was lost in a flood.
An alligator cannot stick out its tongue.
Saudi Arabia imports sand from Australia for construction purposes.
Venus is the only planet in our solar system that rotates clockwise.
The longest English word without a repeating letter is 'uncopyrightable' at 15 letters.
Elephants are the only mammals that can't jump.
rounds.correctWord: not the only (hippos, rhinos, sloths also can't)

rounds.text: The Hawaiian pizza was invented in Hawaii.
There are fewer trees on Earth than stars in the Milky Way galaxy.
rounds.correctWord: more (roughly 3 trillion trees vs. 100-400 billion stars)

rounds.text: The Amazon rainforest produces 20% of the world's oxygen, earning it the title 'lungs of the Earth.'
rounds.correctWord: roughly 0% net (it consumes nearly as much as it produces)

rounds.text: Nero played the fiddle while Rome burned.
rounds.correctWord: nothing (the fiddle hadn't been invented; he likely wasn't even in Rome)

rounds.text: The tongue map shows that sweetness is detected only at the tip of the tongue.
rounds.correctWord: across all areas (the tongue map is a myth)

rounds.text: George Washington had wooden teeth.
rounds.correctWord: ivory, gold, and animal bone (never wood)

rounds.text: Toilets flush in opposite directions in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres due to the Coriolis effect.
rounds.correctWord: whichever direction the basin shape determines (the Coriolis effect is too weak)

rounds.text: MSG commonly causes headaches, known as 'Chinese Restaurant Syndrome.'
rounds.correctWord: has never been scientifically linked to headaches

rounds.text: Shaving makes hair grow back thicker and darker.
rounds.correctWord: the same thickness (blunt cut creates the illusion)

rounds.text: Bulls become enraged by the color red.
rounds.correctWord: movement of the cape (bulls are colorblind to red)

rounds.text: Humans have exactly five senses: sight, hearing, taste, smell, and touch.
rounds.correctWord: far more than five (balance, temperature, pain, etc.)

rounds.text: Sugar causes hyperactivity in children.
rounds.correctWord: has no proven link to hyperactivity

rounds.text: Coca-Cola invented the modern image of Santa Claus — before their ads, he wore green.
rounds.correctWord: popularized (Santa was already depicted in red before Coca-Cola)

rounds.text: Dropping a penny from the Empire State Building could kill a pedestrian below.
Dogs see the world entirely in black and white.
rounds.correctWord: muted blues and yellows (limited color, not grayscale)

rounds.text: Swallowed gum takes seven years to digest.
rounds.correctWord: a few days (it passes through undigested)

rounds.text: The iron maiden was a widely used medieval torture device.
rounds.correctWord: 19th century hoax (no evidence of medieval use)

rounds.text: Taste buds for different flavors are organized in distinct zones across the tongue.
rounds.correctWord: all areas equally (the tongue map is a myth)

rounds.text: The far side of the Moon is always dark because it never receives sunlight.
rounds.correctWord: lit by the Sun half the time (it just never faces Earth)

rounds.text: Touching a baby bird will cause its mother to reject it because of the human scent.
rounds.correctWord: continue caring for (most birds have a poor sense of smell)

rounds.text: Turkey makes you especially sleepy because of its high tryptophan content.
rounds.correctWord: no more than chicken or cheese (they have similar levels)

rounds.text: You must wait 24 hours before filing a missing person report with the police.
rounds.correctWord: can file immediately (no waiting period exists)

rounds.text: The Forbidden City in Beijing has exactly 9,999 rooms.
Searing meat seals in the juices.
rounds.correctWord: does not seal in juices (it creates flavor through the Maillard reaction)

rounds.text: The average person swallows eight spiders per year in their sleep.
Cracking your knuckles causes arthritis.
rounds.correctWord: has no proven link to arthritis

rounds.text: Christopher Columbus set out to prove the Earth was round.
rounds.correctWord: find a westward route to Asia (educated people already knew Earth was round)

rounds.text: The Coriolis effect causes water to drain in opposite directions in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.
rounds.correctWord: is too weak to affect (drain direction depends on basin shape)

rounds.text: Microwave ovens cook food from the inside out.
Lemmings commit mass suicide by running off cliffs.
rounds.correctWord: do not (this myth was staged for a 1958 Disney documentary)

rounds.text: Twinkies have a shelf life of approximately 50 years.
Alcohol kills brain cells permanently.
rounds.correctWord: damages connections between neurons (does not kill cells outright)

rounds.text: A duck's quack produces no echo.
rounds.correctWord: an echo like any other sound

rounds.text: Undercover police officers must identify themselves if asked directly.
rounds.correctWord: are not required to identify themselves

rounds.text: The Great Fire of London in 1666 killed thousands of people.
Daddy longlegs are the most venomous spiders, but their fangs can't pierce human skin.
rounds.correctWord: not spiders at all, and not particularly venomous

rounds.text: You lose most of your body heat through your head.
Marie Antoinette said 'Let them eat cake' in response to bread shortages.
rounds.correctWord: no verified speaker (the phrase predates her by decades)

rounds.text: Eating carrots significantly improves your night vision.
rounds.correctWord: does not improve (British WWII propaganda to hide radar technology)

rounds.text: Spinach is exceptionally high in iron compared to other vegetables.
rounds.correctWord: moderately (a decimal error in 1870 inflated the number by 10x)

rounds.text: Pure water conducts electricity well.
rounds.correctWord: Impurities in water (pure water is a poor conductor)

rounds.text: Seasons are caused by the Earth's distance from the Sun varying throughout the year.
The three states of matter are solid, liquid, and gas.
The Salem Witch Trials resulted in accused witches being burned at the stake.
rounds.correctWord: hanged (burning was common in Europe but not Salem)

rounds.text: Camels store water in their humps for long desert treks.
The term 'computer bug' originated when a moth was found in an IBM mainframe.
Van Gogh never sold a single painting during his lifetime.
The standard marathon distance of 26.2 miles was set at the first modern Olympics in 1896.
rounds.correctWord: 1908 London Olympics (to accommodate the Royal Family's viewing spot)

rounds.text: Mount Everest is the tallest mountain on Earth by any measurement.
rounds.correctWord: elevation above sea level only (Mauna Kea is taller base-to-peak)

rounds.text: Panama hats originate from Panama.
Your fingernails continue to grow after you die.
rounds.correctWord: do not grow (skin dehydrates and retracts, creating the illusion)

rounds.text: Adding salt to water makes it boil significantly faster.
rounds.correctWord: negligibly faster (the effect is too small to matter)

rounds.text: The Bermuda Triangle has a statistically higher rate of disappearances than other ocean regions.
rounds.correctWord: comparable (no statistical anomaly when accounting for traffic volume)

rounds.text: Handling a toad can give you warts.
rounds.correctWord: not give you warts (warts are caused by human papillomavirus)

rounds.text: The five-second rule means food dropped on the floor is safe if picked up quickly.
Thomas Crapper invented the flush toilet.
rounds.correctWord: popularized (Sir John Harington invented it ~200 years earlier)

rounds.text: The Earth's core is hotter than the surface of the Moon.
Antarctica is classified as a country with no permanent population.
Frankenstein is the name of the monster in Mary Shelley's novel.
Humans evolved from chimpanzees.
rounds.correctWord: from a common ancestor shared with chimpanzees

rounds.text: The Declaration of Independence was signed on July 4th, 1776.
rounds.correctWord: adopted on July 4th (most delegates signed on August 2nd)

rounds.text: Mount Rushmore depicts four presidents who all served consecutive terms.
A camel's long eyelashes evolved primarily to attract mates.
rounds.correctWord: keep sand out of their eyes

rounds.text: Macbeth was Shakespeare's longest play.
Saturn is the only planet in our solar system with rings.
rounds.correctWord: one of four (Jupiter, Uranus, and Neptune also have rings)

rounds.text: Every single one of a human's 10,000 taste buds is located on the tongue.
rounds.correctWord: Not all (also found on the roof of the mouth, throat, and esophagus)

rounds.text: Arabic numerals (0-9) were invented by Arab mathematicians.
Coffee is made from roasted coffee beans.
rounds.correctWord: seeds (they are the pits of coffee cherries)

rounds.text: The Hundred Years' War lasted a total of 75 years.
Dolphins sleep with both eyes closed, relying on their pod for protection.
rounds.correctWord: one eye open (half their brain stays awake)

rounds.text: The word 'gymnasium' comes from a Latin word meaning 'exercise hall.'
Black holes are visible as dark spots against the background of space.
rounds.correctWord: invisible (detected by their effect on surrounding matter)

rounds.text: Alexander the Great was Greek and came from Athens.
Bananas are slightly radioactive because they contain uranium.
The Richter scale measures earthquake intensity on a linear scale from 1 to 10.
Sloths can hold their breath underwater for up to 5 minutes.
French fries originated in France.
A group of crows is called a herd.
The Mona Lisa was stolen from the Louvre in 1911 by a Spanish waiter.
Diamonds are the hardest natural substance, and they are indestructible.
rounds.correctWord: can be shattered, burned, or crushed

rounds.text: The Nile River flows south to north, making it the only major river to do so.
rounds.correctWord: one of many (rivers flow based on elevation, not compass direction)

rounds.text: Benjamin Franklin formally proposed the turkey as America's national bird.
rounds.correctWord: only jokingly mentioned in a private letter to his daughter

rounds.text: Teflon was invented by NASA for the space program.
The average lifespan of a housefly is 24 hours.
Hair grows faster when cut regularly.
rounds.correctWord: at the same rate regardless of cutting

rounds.text: The original Monopoly game was invented by Charles Darrow in 1935.
Eating before swimming increases the risk of drowning.
rounds.correctWord: has no proven connection to drowning risk

rounds.text: The Great Pyramid of Giza was built by slaves.
Pluto was reclassified from a planet to a dwarf planet in 2006 because it was too small.
Poinsettias are highly poisonous to humans and pets.
Hair and nails are made of the same protein as rhino horns — collagen.
The term 'third world' originally referred to impoverished nations.
rounds.correctWord: countries not aligned with NATO or the Soviet Bloc

rounds.text: Velcro was invented after a scientist noticed cockleburs sticking to his cat's fur.
The tallest mountain in Greece is Mount Olympus, standing at over 15,000 feet.
Elephants are genuinely afraid of mice.
rounds.correctWord: not particularly afraid of mice (this is a myth)

rounds.text: The @ symbol was invented specifically for email by Ray Tomlinson in 1971.
Polar bears have white fur to blend in with snow.
rounds.correctWord: transparent (it appears white because of light reflection)

rounds.text: A penny dropped from the Empire State Building can reach terminal velocity fast enough to crack the sidewalk.
Eskimos have over 50 words for snow.
rounds.correctWord: roughly the same number as English (the claim is a persistent myth)

rounds.text: The Leaning Tower of Pisa was designed to lean as an architectural feature.
rounds.correctWord: began leaning during construction due to soft soil

rounds.text: Adding oil to pasta water prevents noodles from sticking together.
rounds.correctWord: mostly prevents sauce from clinging to the noodles

rounds.text: The color orange was named long before the fruit was discovered.
rounds.correctWord: after (the fruit was known in English first)

rounds.text: The tallest waterfall in the world is Niagara Falls.
A tomato is a vegetable, both culinarily and botanically.
rounds.correctWord: culinarily but not botanically (it's a botanical fruit)

rounds.text: The Aztec Empire was destroyed by Spanish conquistadors led by Hernán Cortés in the 1600s.
Hummingbirds are one of many bird species that can fly backwards.
The Pacific Ocean got its name from Ferdinand Magellan, who found it calmer than the Atlantic Ocean.
rounds.correctWord: Strait of Magellan (he compared it to the stormy strait he had just crossed)

rounds.text: Istanbul was formerly known as Alexandria and later Constantinople.
Humans have exactly five senses: sight, smell, taste, touch, and hearing.
rounds.correctWord: at least nine (including balance, proprioception, temperature, pain)

rounds.text: Helicopters will fall like a rock if the engine fails.
Watching TV in the dark permanently damages your eyesight.
rounds.correctWord: may cause temporary eye strain but not permanent damage

rounds.text: The Titanic was described as 'unsinkable' by its manufacturers before the voyage.
rounds.correctWord: the press (the White Star Line never officially used the word)

rounds.text: Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa and is part of a larger mountain range.
rounds.wrongWord: part of a larger mountain range
rounds.correctWord: a freestanding volcanic mountain (not part of a range)

rounds.text: Thomas Jefferson wrote the Constitution of the United States.
Koalas are a species of bear native to Australia.
Humans have more brain cells than there are stars in the Milky Way.
rounds.correctWord: fewer (86 billion neurons vs. 100-400 billion stars)

rounds.text: Chewing gum takes seven years to pass through your digestive system.
rounds.correctWord: a few days (it passes through undigested)

rounds.text: Alfred Nobel created the Nobel Peace Prize out of pride in his invention of dynamite.
Pythons kill prey by crushing their bones with brute force.
The Moon has no gravitational pull whatsoever.
Reading in dim light permanently weakens your eyesight.
The original meaning of 'blood is thicker than water' was that family bonds are the strongest.
rounds.correctWord: debated — some scholars argue the full phrase meant bonds forged in battle outweigh family

rounds.text: Mussolini is famously credited with making Italy's trains run on time.
rounds.correctWord: falsely credited (Italian trains were not notably punctual under his rule)

rounds.text: Chocolate is toxic to dogs because of its caffeine content.
Sitting too close to the TV will permanently damage children's eyes.
rounds.correctWord: not damage (it may indicate existing nearsightedness)

rounds.text: The country commonly called Holland is officially named Holland.
rounds.correctWord: the Netherlands (Holland is only two provinces)

rounds.text: Goldfish have a memory span of about three seconds.
Vitamin C prevents the common cold.
rounds.correctWord: may slightly reduce duration but does not prevent

rounds.text: The Amazon River is the longest river in the world.
Starfish are a type of fish, as their name suggests.
rounds.correctWord: echinoderm (they are now officially called 'sea stars')

rounds.text: The Wright Brothers' first flight at Kitty Hawk lasted about 2 minutes.
Freezing batteries helps them last significantly longer.
rounds.correctWord: no meaningful difference (and can damage some types)

rounds.text: The French phrase 'qu'ils mangent de la brioche' was originally about croissants, not cake.
Penguins mate for life, returning to the same partner every breeding season.
rounds.correctWord: for one season (most species choose new partners each year)

rounds.text: The first computer programmer was a man named Charles Babbage.
Eating chocolate causes acne.
rounds.correctWord: has no proven direct link to acne

rounds.text: The Pacific Ring of Fire contains roughly 25% of the world's active volcanoes.
Bubble wrap was originally invented as a packaging material.
Vikings named Iceland and Greenland to trick settlers — Iceland was green and Greenland was icy.
rounds.correctWord: reflect actual conditions when they arrived (Iceland had ice, Greenland had a green coast)

rounds.text: Humans and dinosaurs coexisted for a brief period in Earth's history.
An average cumulus cloud weighs roughly 2,000 pounds.
A cockroach can survive for days without its head before dying.
Antibiotics are effective against both bacteria and viruses.
rounds.correctWord: only (antibiotics do not work against viruses)

rounds.text: High heels were originally designed for women's fashion in 17th century France.
Elephants are the only animals on Earth that can't jump.
rounds.correctWord: one of several (hippos, rhinos, and sloths also can't)

rounds.text: A solar day on Mercury lasts roughly 30 Earth days.
Neanderthals were unintelligent brutes compared to Homo sapiens.
rounds.correctWord: comparable in brain size and capable of art, tools, and burial rituals

rounds.text: The first email was sent in 1991, the same year the World Wide Web launched.
Giraffes have more neck vertebrae than humans.
rounds.correctWord: the same number (7, just much larger)

rounds.text: The word 'testify' comes from the Roman practice of men placing a hand on their heart in court.
A black belt in karate signifies the highest level of mastery.
rounds.correctWord: intermediate (there are multiple degrees above the initial black belt)

rounds.text: Henry Ford invented the automobile.
rounds.correctWord: popularized affordable (Karl Benz invented the first true automobile)

rounds.text: A lightning bolt reaches temperatures of about 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit — roughly the same as the Sun's surface.
rounds.correctWord: 50,000 (five times hotter than the Sun's surface)

rounds.text: The wasabi served in most restaurants outside Japan is real wasabi.
rounds.correctWord: dyed horseradish (real wasabi is rare and expensive)

rounds.text: The Statue of Liberty is made of bronze.
Albert Einstein had a verified IQ of 160, tested during his time at Princeton.
rounds.correctWord: estimated (he was never formally IQ tested)

rounds.text: Caesar salad is named after Julius Caesar.
Banging the side of an old TV to fix it was purely superstition with no basis in reality.
rounds.correctWord: sometimes effective (loose solder joints could resettle from impact)

rounds.text: Tarzan's famous yell in the movies was performed by Johnny Weissmuller himself.
rounds.correctWord: a combination of recordings (its exact origin is debated)

rounds.text: Organic food is grown completely without pesticides.
rounds.correctWord: without synthetic pesticides (organic farming uses approved natural pesticides)

rounds.text: The second law of thermodynamics states that entropy always increases in a closed system.
rounds.correctWord: tends to (entropy is statistical, not absolute)

rounds.text: Cleopatra ruled Egypt around 300 BC, during the height of the pharaohs.
Celery has negative calories — digesting it burns more energy than the celery contains.
rounds.correctWord: very few but still positive calories (digestion doesn't create a deficit)

rounds.text: The blood of horseshoe crabs is red and has no special medical use.
rounds.correctWord: blue (and is used to test medical equipment for bacterial contamination)

rounds.text: Medieval Europeans widely believed the Earth was flat.
rounds.correctWord: knew the Earth was spherical (this was established since ancient Greece)

rounds.text: Dogs age at a rate of exactly seven human years for every dog year.
rounds.correctWord: varies widely by breed and size (the 7:1 ratio is a myth)

rounds.text: Wi-Fi stands for 'Wireless Fidelity.'
rounds.correctWord: nothing (it's a brand name that doesn't stand for anything)

rounds.text: The Eiffel Tower was intended to be a permanent fixture of the Paris skyline from the start.
rounds.correctWord: temporary (built for the 1889 World's Fair, planned to be dismantled after 20 years)

rounds.text: Porcupines can shoot their quills at predators from a distance.
rounds.correctWord: cannot shoot (quills detach on contact only)

rounds.text: Both male and female mosquitoes bite humans for blood.
Thomas Edison single-handedly invented the light bulb.
rounds.correctWord: improved and commercialized (earlier versions existed by Davy, Swan, and others)

rounds.text: The space between your eyebrows is called the 'bridge.'
Touching a butterfly's wings will kill it by removing essential scales.
rounds.correctWord: not kill it (they can fly with many scales missing)

rounds.text: The Great Wall of China is a single continuous wall stretching across northern China.
rounds.correctWord: a network of walls and fortifications with many gaps

rounds.text: Drinking milk increases mucus production when you have a cold.
rounds.correctWord: does not increase mucus (multiple studies have debunked this)

rounds.text: The term 'cop' comes from officers' copper badges in early New York.
rounds.correctWord: the verb 'to cop' meaning to capture or seize

rounds.text: Cats always land on their feet, even when dropped from just a few inches.
rounds.correctWord: at least about a foot (they need time to rotate)

rounds.text: George Washington Carver invented peanut butter.
rounds.correctWord: developed hundreds of peanut products but did not invent peanut butter

rounds.text: The human heart is located on the left side of the chest.
rounds.correctWord: center (it is tilted slightly left but sits mostly in the middle)

rounds.text: Sound cannot travel through a vacuum, and neither can light.
rounds.correctWord: but light can (electromagnetic waves don't need a medium)

rounds.text: The human body contains four kidneys.
Quicksand can fully swallow a person who falls into it.
rounds.correctWord: only submerge about waist deep (human density is less than quicksand)

rounds.text: The 'D' in D-Day stands for 'Doom.'
rounds.correctWord: Day (D-Day is standard military terminology for the start date of any operation)

rounds.text: Sharks kill more people per year than any other animal on Earth.
Sunflowers track the Sun across the sky throughout their entire lives.
rounds.correctWord: only while young (mature sunflowers face east permanently)

rounds.text: A frog placed in slowly heated water will stay in the pot and boil to death.
rounds.correctWord: jump out (the boiling frog metaphor is a myth)

rounds.text: The word 'avocado' comes from an Aztec word meaning 'green fruit.'
The Celsius and Fahrenheit scales intersect at -20 degrees.
A caterpillar has more muscles than a human — about 248.
The plastic tips on shoelaces are called 'nibs.'
The Mongol Empire was the largest empire in history by land area.
Albert Einstein was born in Austria and later became an American citizen.
The tallest building in the world as of 2025 is the Shanghai Tower.
Cutting an earthworm in half produces two living worms.
rounds.correctWord: usually one surviving half (the tail typically dies)

rounds.text: White chocolate's primary ingredient is chocolate liquor.
rounds.correctWord: cocoa butter (white chocolate contains no cocoa solids)

rounds.text: Saturn is so dense that it would sink immediately if placed in water.
rounds.correctWord: float (its average density is less than water)

rounds.text: The ampersand (&) was invented in the 20th century for typewriters.
The Mona Lisa has clearly visible eyebrows that frame her famous expression.
Coffee was discovered by a shepherd who noticed his sheep becoming energetic after eating coffee berries.
Russia sold Alaska to the United States for $72 million in 1867.
The platypus is one of only two mammals that lay eggs.
rounds.correctWord: five (platypus and four species of echidna)

rounds.text: The shortest complete sentence in the English language is 'I am.'
Humans can distinguish between about 100 different colors.
The Bermuda Triangle is officially recognized by the US Navy as a dangerous zone.
rounds.correctWord: not recognized (neither the US Navy nor Coast Guard considers it unusually hazardous)

rounds.text: Microwaving food destroys most of its nutrients.
rounds.correctWord: preserves more nutrients than many other cooking methods

rounds.text: A goldfish will grow to match the size of its bowl through adaptive growth.
rounds.correctWord: stunted growth (small bowls cause health problems, not healthy adaptation)

rounds.text: The three primary colors of light are red, yellow, and blue.
The White House was always officially called the 'White House' since its construction.
rounds.correctWord: not until 1901 (Theodore Roosevelt made it the official name)

rounds.text: Owls can rotate their heads a full 360 degrees.
Rust forms when iron reacts with nitrogen in the air.
The longest bone in the human body is the tibia.
Marie Curie's research notebooks have been fully decontaminated and are safe to handle.
rounds.correctWord: still radioactive (stored in lead-lined boxes, require protective gear to handle)

rounds.text: The five Olympic rings represent five continents: Africa, the Americas, Europe, Asia, and Antarctica.
The human body contains enough carbon to fill 900 pencils.
A jiffy is just an informal expression meaning 'a short time' with no precise measurement.
rounds.correctWord: a precise unit (1/100th second in computing, light travel of 1 cm in physics)

rounds.text: Napoleon lost the Battle of Waterloo to a British army led by Winston Churchill.
Flamingos are naturally pink from birth.
rounds.correctWord: born white/grey (they turn pink from carotenoids in their diet)

rounds.text: The first country to give women the right to vote was the United States in 1920.
The correct plural of 'octopus' is 'octopi.'
rounds.correctWord: octopuses (or octopodes — 'octopi' wrongly applies Latin rules to a Greek word)

rounds.text: Trees get most of their mass from nutrients in the soil absorbed through their roots.
rounds.correctWord: carbon dioxide in the air (through photosynthesis)

rounds.text: Whales evolved from land-dwelling mammals that resembled large wolves.
Honey is technically bee vomit from their main digestive stomach.
rounds.correctWord: a separate honey stomach (crop), not the digestive stomach

rounds.text: The longest river entirely within one country is the Mississippi in the United States.
Astronauts on the International Space Station experience zero gravity.
rounds.correctWord: microgravity (they are in freefall, not beyond gravity's reach)

rounds.text: The speed of sound is constant regardless of temperature or altitude.
Vikings were primarily raiders with no interest in trade or farming.
rounds.wrongWord: no interest in trade or farming

rounds.text: A chameleon's tongue is roughly half the length of its body.
